Award.AwardTitle: High Resolution Single Molecule Analysis of Fast Folding and its Coupling to Binding

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proteins are the cellular nanomachines in charge of most biological functions, including energy production, DNA replication and transcription, enzymatic catalysis, signaling, cellular scaffolding and defense. But proteins are also inherently flexible polymers that must fold into the complex native 3D structures corresponding to their biologically functional states in a self-assembly process determined by the chemical blueprints encoded in their amino acid sequence. Thus the mechanisms by which proteins fold and function are a critical component of almost every aspect of molecular and cell biology. Understanding the intertwined mechanisms of folding and function also brings about the opportunity to predict, engineer, and design biological function "a la carte", thus conveying unparalleled transformative impact to Society. Moreover, because proteins are at the lowest echelon of biological complexity where Biology effectively meets Physics, Chemistry, and Engineering, their study constitutes an ideal arena for training the new generations of multidisciplinary researchers, preparing them for the emerging fields of Quantitative and Synthetic Biology. Activities are designed around a team-based structure aimed at facilitating integration of members at various levels of education ranging from postdoctoral fellows and graduate students to undergraduate and high school students/teachers. An equally important element of this project is the strong commitment to participation of underrepresented groups in research. The PI will actively recruit project members from several existing research mentoring programs for underrepresented minorities in STEM fields to participate in the research activities of this project.

A major drive for modern protein research has been to develop experimental methods to resolve the myriads of pathways and complex mechanisms that are predicted by advanced theory and atomistic molecular simulations. Detecting such inherent kinetic complexity in experiments has remained elusive, even with modern methods that exhibit improved time, structural, or single-molecule resolution. The overall objective of this project is to bridge this gap by experimentally monitoring the transition paths of individual protein molecules as they fold. Advanced single-molecule fluorescence methods will be used in conjunction with theoretical and computational analyses to measure transition paths and folding mechanisms of fast-folding protein domains. Fast-folding domains are optimal targets because their marginal cooperativity ensures significant populations of "excited" states and, somewhat counterintuitively, slower transition paths over their broad, shallow folding barriers. Moreover, the microsecond folding of these domains facilitates direct comparison with modern atomistic simulations. To reach the required resolution, we rely on approaches we recently developed for achieving microsecond resolution single-molecule fluorescence detection, such as better photoprotection systems and procedures for maximum likelihood analysis of photon arrival times, together with implementation of 2-color and 3-color FRET schemes to measure multiple distances. Through the realization of these experiments and computational analyses on select fast-folding domains we will investigate the structural, sequence, and environmental determinants of the mechanisms for folding.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An issue of major contention in the protein folding field has been the discrepancy between theory and computer simulations, which predict a complex and heterogenous process where each protein molecule follows a distinct microscopic path through a corrugated, but broadly funneled energy landscape, and experiments, which have consistently revealed an apparently simple, all-or-none process that makes it a challenge to distill the underlying mechanisms.

Goals: In this project our goal was to develop experimental methodologies and approaches that could resolve this discrepancy and provide the type of experimental benchmarks required for testing and refining theoretical models and simulations. Our contention was that the solution required two factors: 1) the need to achieve direct experimental detection of individual protein molecules while in transit between their unfolded and native states; 2) because crossing a high free energy barrier upon folding makes the actual transitions too rare and too sudden, perhaps counterintuitively, one should start by applying these techniques to the fastest folding proteins.

Achievements: To detect the actual molecular transition paths of microsecond folding proteins we needed to implement tailored methodologies to manipulate these marginally-stable proteins without perturbing their folding behavior, employ advanced techniques for single-molecule fluorescence and force detection, design strategies to bypass the time-resolution constraints of existing single-molecule technology, and develop powerful analytical methods to extract the sought-after mechanistic information. During the three years of the project we have worked on all these technical aspects and have produced a suite of experimental protocols, techniques and approaches for the direct observation of fast-folding proteins while stochastically interconverting between their unfolded and native states.

As model systems we studied four protein domains (EngHD, gpW and two WW domains) that fold in microseconds into structures that share an all-antiparallel topology but feature different secondary structures (alpha-helix, mixed alpha-beta, and all beta), and/or aminoacid sequence.  We characterized their folding-unfolding thermodynamics and kinetics using bulk experiments and discovered that they all seemed to cross a minimal free energy barrier to folding, but, at the same time featured notable differences in rates. These results defied the conventional paradigm, which dictates that changes in rates solely reflect changes in barrier, and they confirmed that the four domains were ideal candidates for single-molecule studies. From a sample viewpoint, we implemented methods to non-invasively introduce extrinsic fluorophore pairs for fluorescence imaging, and molecular tethers for mechanical manipulation. We optimized the single-molecule fluorescence experiments to maximize the photon detection count-rate (defines the ultimate time-resolution), and single-molecule force spectroscopy experiments to catch the folding-unfolding interconversions of mechanically pliable, fast-folding domains. As another key methodological development, we implemented advanced maximum likelihood approaches to extract all mechanistic details from the series of photon color and arrival times that are typically measured by single-molecule fluorescence imaging so we could directly extract the shape of the folding free energy surface, the height of the barrier, and the intramolecular diffusion coefficient.  

Equipped with all these advances, we have demonstrated that it is possible to resolve the folding and unfolding transition paths of individual fast-folding protein molecules using either fluorescence detection in chemical denaturation or force detection during mechanical unfolding. From these experiments we have made key observations that shed much needed light into the microscopic determinants of protein folding reactions. For instance, we confirmed that, at their denaturation midpoint, all these proteins fold over marginal free energy barriers that are actually induced by the chemical denaturant or force. We have resolved their transition path times, as well as their intramolecular diffusion coefficients, results that directly connect with theory and simulations. We have also studied the effects of the instrumental response time in measurements of folding-unfolding transitions, and discovered that, for fast-folding proteins, their effects in rates and transition path times are equivalents, and thus do not seriously perturb the measured free energy surface.    

Broader Impacts: The project has offered unique training opportunities in the field of molecular biophysics for engineers, chemists and physicists at the postdoc, graduate and undergraduate student level,s with the overall goal of training them to become the future cohorts of bio-researchers and bioengineers. In collaboration with the NSF Center for Cellular and Biomolecular Machines (CCBM), and taking advantage of the unique demographics of UC Merced, this project and lab has engaged multiple undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, particularly first-generation college goers and people of Hispanic culture/origin, in advanced biophysics research. The project has also provided summer research training to URM undergraduate students from the California State University system via the C-SIP program run by CCBM, and African American high school students through participation in the ACS SEED program.
